comments.body:
for reference:
https://github.com/kubernetes/test-infra/pull/14030
https://github.com/kubernetes/release/issues/854#issuecomment-524071615

`k8s-master` on the other hand is a label that i don't fully understand.
if you look here there are more `k8s-*` labels but i don't think we should support them in kubeadm for now.
https://console.cloud.google.com/storage/browser/kubernetes-release-dev/ci?pli=1

so i'm fine with the replacement this PR is doing.
Yeah, I agree. k8s-master can be used to verify the cross builds for kubernetes when used with kubeadm as and when the builds become available.

This section tests release versions. However, afaiu k8s-master doesn't contain a specific version, but it keeps changing based on the latest cross builds available. So, it won't be possible to test k8s-master with a specific version. I guess that's the same reason why we don't test ci/latest in this particular testing. Please correct me if my understanding is wrong here.
we need also test cases here for at least `v1.8.2`, `v1.9.11-beta.0`, `v1.11.3-beta.0.38+135cc4c1f47994`

Here we are not doing fallback because base version is `1.x.0`, thus there is no guarantee that there is official `1.8.0` release and we don't know what was previous stable release in `1.7.x` branch. Thus, if kubeadm version is `1.8.0-alpha.2.xxxxx` it is safe to conclude that `1.8.0-alpha.2` was published. There is might be already `1.8.0-alpha.3` or higher, but kubeadm at this point doesn't have information about that. So, fallback version should be "highest official build that we can determine without network access", but less or equal to kubeadm's version.

Rationale: our default is `stable-1.x`, so as user I would expect that I'll get some stable version from the same branch as kubeadm, not random build. This will be consistent with default, and for kubeadm builds like `1.x.0*`, where the best `stable` are latest betas or latest release candidates, until it released. This way allows user by default try to install latest stable released version that is not newer than kubeadm. This also allows users to test newer versions of kubeadm, but still by default get stable build.
ok, we can leave it the way it is. hopefully we don't confuse the users.
